instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2337: What is A2337? A2337 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2020 M1 with EMC 3598, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02016..
definitions.820-02016: What is 820-02016? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hello Everyone,

One of my customers brought me a macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> , probably board number <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> after contact with liquid . He was in another service. When I plugged it in I can see that it stays around 5.090V and amp goes up to between 0.09 and 0.14. And it is on a loop like this.  I can't find the Boardview.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> stable?

[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1B_VwIwrRUpmztDO1ruVUfIIQWoaRAhuU/view?usp=sharing[/URL]

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
[I]Is not stable, jumps from 8.5v to 12.3v.
<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> stable 3.8v[/I]

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Remove F5200 and check if get stable voltage at <CAPACITOR>C5254</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I replaced the F5200 and still  jumps from 8.5v to 12.3v.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Who said to replace F5200???
Please, pay atention when read the posts...

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Sorry, my mistake.
<CAPACITOR>C5254</CAPACITOR> has a steady 12.3v.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Check for short on all big coils.
Compare readings with good board.

Also check if <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> deliver some voltages.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Unfortunately, I don't have the same motherboard.
L5800 - 22M oHM
L5820 - 7M OHM
L5840 - 7M OHM
LP800 - 2860K OHM
L5230 - 250K OHM
LC320 - 170K OHM
Should I restore the F5200 before checking the <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> ?

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Of course, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> must be present.

BTW, use diode mode for checking on the coils.
Switch to ohm mode only for low values; usually under 0.005-0.010 readings (diode mode).

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Big coils are ok. 
<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> 3.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_VLDOINT_MPMU</SIGNAL>  1.5v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_BSTLQ_MPMU</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_IMEAS</SIGNAL>  0.03v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S2_PWR_EN_MPMU</SIGNAL> pulsing to 1.1v
<SIGNAL>PVDD1_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> pulsing to 1.1v
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_LPM</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PMU_RESET_L</SIGNAL>  pulsing to 0.6v
<SIGNAL>BUCK4_LX0</SIGNAL> <SIGNAL>PP1V06_S2SW_DRAM</SIGNAL>  pulsing to 0.6v
<SIGNAL>PP0V764_S1_SRAM</SIGNAL> pulsing to 0.6v
<SIGNAL>PP0V72_S2_VDD_LOW</SIGNAL>  pulsing to 0.5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_S2</SIGNAL> pulsing to 0.9v
<SIGNAL>PPVDD_PMU_LDO_PREREG</SIGNAL> pulsing to 1v

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: If <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> is stable, you should get the LDOs from <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Right...
<SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> is stable - 3.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_VLDOINT_MPMU</SIGNAL> stable 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> 3.8v stable

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Check master PMU VLDOs; page 34, bottom side; skip NC_ rails.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> - 3.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_VLDOINT_MPMU</SIGNAL> - 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S2</SIGNAL> - pulsing to 0.8v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2_UPC</SIGNAL> - pulsing to 2v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AON_MPMU</SIGNAL> - 1.8v
You can see that the <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> corner is heating up.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground on the small coils around <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>.
Also check if any get voltage pulse (if not shorted).

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I checked all:
L8120 - diode-mode: 0.01 - pulsing to 0.5v
L8121 - diode-mode: 0.01 - pulsing to 0.5v
L8271 - diode-mode: 0.150 - pulsing to 0.5v
L8270 - diode-mode: 0.150 - pulsing to 0.5v
L82B1 - diode-mode: 0.05 - pulsing to 0.5v
L82B0 - diode-mode: 0.05 - pulsing to 0.5V
L8100 - diode-mode: 0.1 - pulsing to 0.5v
L8101 - diode-mode: 0.01 - pulsing to 0.5v
L8102 - diode-mode: 0.01 - pulsing to 0.5v
L8112 - diode-mode: 0.01 - 0v
L8111 - diode-mode: 0.01 - 0v
L8110 - diode-mode: 0.1 - 0v
L8280 - diode-mode: 0.05 - pulsing to 0.5v
L8281 - diode-mode: 0.05 - pulsing to 0.5v
L8290 - diode-mode: 0.18 - pulsing to 0.5v
L84E0 - diode-mode: 0.3 - pulsing to 0.9v
L8230 - diode-mode: 0.5 - 0V
L22A0 - diode-mode: 0.1 - pulsing to 0.5V
L7741 - diode-mode: 0.03 - pulsing to 0.8v
L7740 - diode-mode: 0.03 - pulsing to 0.8v
L7750 - diode-mode: 0.2 - pulsing to 0.5v
L77C0 - diode-mode: 0.25 - pulsing to 0.8v
L7760 - diode-mode: 0.3 - pulsing to 0.6v

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Switch to ohm mode for 0.01 readings and compare with good board.
I don't have any here for test.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: [ATTACH type="full"]60818[/ATTACH]

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Can you catch voltage pulse on the big coils?
You may have problems with <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>, or <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>; should change to discard.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
My multimeter sees a stable voltage on the big coils.
I found a short circuit on the line  <SIGNAL>VSS_ANA_MPMU</SIGNAL>, this is where the <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> heats up. Does it make sense ?

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: VSS is a ground pin; no short there (is normal).

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Whether reballing <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> can help ?.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: You can try, but I doubt will help...
